/app/src/ast.rs:
    1|       |//! Abstract Syntax Tree (AST) for C11 compiler.
    2|       |//!
    3|       |//! This module provides the core AST data structures and APIs for representing
    4|       |//! C11 programs. The AST is designed as a flattened storage system for efficiency,
    5|       |//! with index-based references to child nodes and types.
    6|       |//!
    7|       |//! ## Architecture
    8|       |//!
    9|       |//! The AST is organized into focused submodules for better maintainability:
   10|       |//!
   11|       |//! - [`nodes`]: Node definitions, constructors, and builder patterns for AST nodes
   12|       |//! - [`types`]: Type system representation and utilities for semantic analysis
   13|       |//!
   14|       |//! ## Key Features
   15|       |//!
   16|       |//! - **Flattened Storage**: All AST nodes are stored in contiguous vectors with index-based references
   17|       |//! - **Interior Mutability**: Uses `Cell` for type annotations without requiring mutable AST access
   18|       |//! - **Builder Patterns**: Ergonomic constructors for complex AST nodes
   19|       |//! - **Type System**: Canonical types distinct from syntactic type specifiers
   20|       |//!
   21|       |
   22|       |use std::num::NonZeroU32;
   23|       |
   24|       |/// Represents an interned string using symbol_table crate.
   25|       |/// Alias for GlobalSymbol from symbol_table crate with global feature.
   26|       |pub type NameId = symbol_table::GlobalSymbol;
   27|       |

   29|       |pub use crate::source_manager::{SourceId, SourceLoc, SourceSpan};

  151|  6.47k|            self.current += 1;

  154|  3.11k|            None

  293|       |    /// Get function name from symbol entry reference
  294|      4|    fn get_function_name(symbol_ref: SymbolRef, symbol_table: Option<&SymbolTable>) -> String {
  295|      4|        if let Some(table) = symbol_table {
  296|      4|            let entry = table.get_symbol(symbol_ref);

  298|      0|        }
  299|      0|        format!("func_{}", symbol_ref.get())
  300|      4|    }

  302|       |    /// Format a DesignatedInitializer for display
  303|      4|    fn format_designated_initializer(init: &DesignatedInitializer, ast: &Ast) -> String {
  304|      4|        let mut result = String::new();
  305|      4|        for designator_ref in init.designator_start.range(init.designator_len) {
  306|      4|            match ast.get_kind(designator_ref) {
  307|      4|                NodeKind::Designator(d) => match d {
  308|      2|                    Designator::FieldName(name) => {
  309|      2|                        result.push_str(&format!(".{}", name));
  310|      2|                    }
  311|      2|                    Designator::ArrayIndex(index) => {
  312|      2|                        result.push_str(&format!("[{}]", index.get()));
  313|      2|                    }
  314|      0|                    Designator::GnuArrayRange(start, end) => {
  315|      0|                        result.push_str(&format!("[{} ... {}]", start.get(), end.get()));
  316|      0|                    }
  317|       |                },
  318|      0|                _ => result.push_str("<invalid designator>"),
  319|       |            }
  320|       |        }
  321|       |
  322|      4|        if init.designator_len > 0 {
  323|      4|            result.push_str(" = ");
  324|      4|        }
                      ^0
  325|       |
  326|      4|        result.push_str(&init.initializer.get().to_string());
  327|      4|        result
  328|      4|    }

  515|       |    /// Format a single diagnostic with rich source code context
  516|      0|    fn format_diagnostic(&self, diag: &Diagnostic, source_manager: &SourceManager) -> String {

  549|      0|                        .to_str()

    1|       |//! Mid-level Intermediate Representation (MIR) for C11 compiler.
    2|       |//!
    3|       |//! This module provides the MIR data structures and APIs for representing
    4|       |//! C11 programs after semantic analysis. The MIR is designed to be:
    5|       |//! - Typed: All entities have explicit types
    6|       |//! - Explicit: All C semantics are made explicit
    7|       |//! - Cranelift-friendly: Easy to lower to Cranelift IR
    8|       |//! - Non-SSA: Uses basic blocks with explicit control flow
    9|       |
   10|       |use hashbrown::HashMap;

  147|      0|fn f64_to_f128_bytes(val: f64) -> [u8; 16] {
  148|      0|    let bits = val.to_bits();
  149|      0|    let sign = (bits >> 63) & 1;
  150|      0|    let exp = (bits >> 52) & 0x7FF;
  151|      0|    let mant = bits & 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFF;
  152|       |
  153|      0|    let (new_exp, new_mant) = if exp == 0 {
  154|      0|        if mant == 0 {
  155|       |            // Zero
  156|      0|            (0, 0)
  157|       |        } else {
  158|       |            // Subnormal f64 -> Normal f128
  159|       |            // mant is 0.bbbb... (52 bits)
  160|      0|            let lz = mant.leading_zeros() - (64 - 52);
  161|      0|            let shift = lz + 1;
  162|      0|            let normalized_mant = mant << shift;
  163|      0|            let payload = normalized_mant & 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFF; // 52 bits
  164|       |
  165|      0|            let unbiased_exp = -1022 - (shift as i32);
  166|      0|            let biased_exp = unbiased_exp + 16383;
  167|       |
  168|      0|            (biased_exp as u64, (payload as u128) << (112 - 52))
  169|       |        }
  170|      0|    } else if exp == 0x7FF {
  171|       |        // Inf or NaN
  172|      0|        (0x7FFF, (mant as u128) << (112 - 52))
  173|       |    } else {
  174|       |        // Normal
  175|      0|        let unbiased_exp = (exp as i32) - 1023;
  176|      0|        let biased_exp = unbiased_exp + 16383;
  177|      0|        (biased_exp as u64, (mant as u128) << (112 - 52))
  178|       |    };
  179|       |
  180|      0|    let sign_bit = (sign as u128) << 127;
  181|      0|    let exp_bits = (new_exp as u128) << 112;
  182|      0|    let mant_bits = new_mant;
  183|       |
  184|      0|    let result = sign_bit | exp_bits | mant_bits;
  185|      0|    result.to_le_bytes()
  186|      0|}
  187|       |
  188|      8|fn f64_to_x87_bytes(val: f64) -> [u8; 16] {
  189|      8|    let bits = val.to_bits();
  190|      8|    let sign = (bits >> 63) & 1;
  191|      8|    let exp = (bits >> 52) & 0x7FF;
  192|      8|    let mant = bits & 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFF;
  193|       |
  194|      8|    let mut out = [0u8; 16];
  195|       |
  196|      8|    if exp == 0 {
  197|      0|        if mant == 0 {
  198|       |            // Zero
  199|      0|            if sign == 1 {
  200|      0|                out[9] = 0x80;
  201|      0|            }
  202|      0|            return out;
  203|      0|        }
  204|       |
  205|       |        // Subnormal f64
  206|       |        // Calculate leading zeros in the 52-bit mantissa
  207|       |        // 12 zeros because u64 has 64 bits but mant only 52
  208|      0|        let lz = mant.leading_zeros() - 12;
  209|       |
  210|       |        // Shift to make MSB 1 (integer bit for x87)
  211|       |        // We want to put the first '1' at bit 63.
  212|       |        // Currently it is at (51 - lz).
  213|       |        // Shift left by 63 - (51 - lz) = 12 + lz.
  214|      0|        let new_mant = mant << (12 + lz);
  215|       |
  216|       |        // Exponent calculation
  217|       |        // Real exponent of f64 subnormal is -1022.
  218|       |        // We effectively shifted left by (lz + 1) to normalize (because we moved 0.1... to 1.0...)
  219|       |        // So we must subtract (lz + 1) from exponent.
  220|      0|        let real_exp = -1022 - (lz as i32 + 1);
  221|       |
  222|       |        // x87 bias 16383
  223|      0|        let new_exp_biased = (real_exp + 16383) as u16;
  224|       |
  225|      0|        out[0..8].copy_from_slice(&new_mant.to_le_bytes());
  226|      0|        out[8..10].copy_from_slice(&new_exp_biased.to_le_bytes());
  227|      0|        if sign == 1 {
  228|      0|            out[9] |= 0x80;
  229|      0|        }
  230|      0|        return out;
  231|      8|    } else if exp == 0x7FF {
  232|       |        // Inf or NaN
  233|      0|        out[8] = 0xFF;
  234|      0|        out[9] = 0x7F | ((sign as u8) << 7);
  235|       |
  236|      0|        if mant == 0 {
  237|      0|            // Infinity: Integer bit 1, mantissa 0
  238|      0|            out[7] = 0x80;
  239|      0|        } else {
  240|      0|            // NaN: Set integer bit 1
  241|      0|            // f64 mantissa is 52 bits. x87 is 63 bits.
  242|      0|            // Shift left by 11.
  243|      0|            let new_mant = (1u64 << 63) | (mant << 11);
  244|      0|            out[0..8].copy_from_slice(&new_mant.to_le_bytes());
  245|      0|        }
  246|      0|        return out;
  247|      8|    }
  248|       |
  249|       |    // Normal f64
  250|      8|    let unbiased_exp = (exp as i32) - 1023;
  251|      8|    let new_exp = (unbiased_exp + 16383) as u16;
  252|       |
  253|       |    // Explicit integer bit 1 for Normal numbers in x87
  254|      8|    let new_mant = (1u64 << 63) | (mant << 11);
  255|       |
  256|      8|    out[0..8].copy_from_slice(&new_mant.to_le_bytes());
  257|      8|    out[8..10].copy_from_slice(&new_exp.to_le_bytes());
  258|       |
  259|       |    // Sign bit in byte 9, bit 7
  260|      8|    if sign == 1 {
  261|      0|        out[9] |= 0x80;
  262|      8|    }
  263|       |
  264|      8|    out
  265|      8|}
  266|       |

  269|      7|    match ty {
  270|      2|        MirType::F32 => {

  297|      4|    ty: &MirType,
  298|      4|    output: &mut Vec<u8>,
  299|      4|    ctx: &EmitContext,
  300|      4|    mut module: Option<&mut ObjectModule>,

  307|       |            field_types: _,

  312|      4|            let mut struct_bytes = vec![0u8; struct_size];

  329|       |                    // Copy the field bytes into the struct buffer
  330|      9|                    let required_size = field_offset + field_bytes.len();

  332|      0|                        struct_bytes.resize(required_size, 0);

  646|       |/// Helper to resolve arguments for a call, handling variadic struct expansion if needed
  647|     25|fn resolve_call_args(
  648|     25|    args: &[Operand],
  649|     25|    fixed_param_count: usize,
  650|     25|    sig: &Signature,
  651|     25|    ctx: &mut BodyEmitContext,
  652|     25|    is_variadic: bool,
  653|     25|    split_f128: bool,
  654|     25|    triple: &Triple,
  655|     25|) -> Result<Vec<Value>, String> {
  656|     25|    let mut arg_values = Vec::new();
  657|     25|    let mut sig_idx = 0;
  658|     25|    let mut xmm_used = 0;
  659|       |
  660|       |    // Count XMM usage from fixed parameters first (checking signatures from ctx.mir logic if needed)
  661|       |    // But here we iterate all args. We need to distinguish fixed params.
  662|       |    // We can assume first `fixed_param_count` args match `sig`'s first params,
  663|       |    // but `sig` might have split params.

  670|     28|            if is_xmm_argument(mir_type) {
  671|      0|                xmm_used += 1;
  672|     28|            }
  673|      0|        }
  674|       |    }
  675|       |
  676|     63|    for (arg_idx, arg) in args.iter().enumerate() {
                                        ^25  ^25    ^25

  683|       |

  687|     28|            && let Some(count) = get_struct_packing(ctx.mir.get_type(type_id), ctx.mir)
                                      ^2

                                                                                 ^0
  691|      2|            let size = mir_type_size(ctx.mir.get_type(type_id), ctx.mir).unwrap_or(8u32);
  692|       |
  693|      2|            for i in 0..count {
  694|       |                // If it's the last chunk, we might need partial load
  695|      2|                let offset = (i * 8) as i32;

  697|       |

  699|      2|                    ctx.builder.ins().load(types::I64, MemFlags::new(), struct_addr, offset)
  700|       |                } else {

  702|      0|                    let mut current_val = ctx.builder.ins().iconst(types::I64, 0);
  703|      0|                    for b in 0..remaining {
  704|      0|                        let byte_val =
  705|      0|                            ctx.builder

  708|      0|                        let byte_ext = ctx.builder.ins().uextend(types::I64, byte_val);

  711|      0|                        current_val = ctx.builder.ins().bor(current_val, shifted);
  712|      0|                    }

 1482|       |/// Helper function to resolve a MIR place to a memory address
 1483|    122|fn resolve_place_to_addr(place: &Place, ctx: &mut BodyEmitContext) -> Result<Value, String> {
 1484|    122|    match place {
 1485|     63|        Place::Local(local_id) => {
 1486|     63|            if let Some(stack_slot) = ctx.stack_slots.get(local_id) {
 1487|     63|                Ok(ctx.builder.ins().stack_addr(types::I64, *stack_slot, 0))
 1488|       |            } else {
 1489|      0|                Err(format!("Stack slot not found for local {}", local_id.get()))
 1490|       |            }
 1491|       |        }
 1492|     16|        Place::Global(global_id) => {
 1493|     16|            let global = ctx.mir.get_global(*global_id);
 1494|     16|            let linkage = if global.initial_value.is_some() {
 1495|     16|                Linkage::Export
 1496|       |            } else {
 1497|      0|                Linkage::Import
 1498|       |            };

 1501|     16|                .module
 1502|     16|                .declare_data(global.name.as_str(), linkage, true, false)

                                           ^0      ^0                                        ^0
 1504|     16|            let local_id = ctx.module.declare_data_in_func(global_val, ctx.builder.func);
 1505|       |            // Use I64 for addresses
 1506|     16|            Ok(ctx.builder.ins().global_value(types::I64, local_id))
 1507|       |        }
 1508|      4|        Place::Deref(operand) => {
 1509|       |            // The address is the value of the operand itself (which should be a pointer).
 1510|      4|            resolve_operand(operand, ctx, types::I64)
 1511|       |        }
 1512|     23|        Place::StructField(base_place, field_index) => {
 1513|       |            // Get the base address of the struct
 1514|     23|            let base_addr = resolve_place_to_addr(base_place, ctx)?;
                                                                                ^0
 1515|       |
 1516|       |            // We need to find the type of the base_place to get the pre-computed field offset
 1517|     23|            let base_place_type_id = get_place_type_id(base_place, ctx.mir);
 1518|     23|            let base_type = ctx.mir.get_type(base_place_type_id);
 1519|       |
 1520|     23|            let (field_offset, is_pointer) = match base_type {
 1521|     23|                MirType::Record { layout, .. } => {
 1522|     23|                    let offset = layout
 1523|     23|                        .field_offsets
 1524|     23|                        .get(*field_index)
 1525|     23|                        .copied()
 1526|     23|                        .ok_or_else(|| format!("Field index {} out of bounds", field_index))?;
                                                     ^0      ^0                                           ^0

 1531|      0|                    if let MirType::Record { layout, .. } = pointee_type {
 1532|      0|                        let offset = layout

 1534|      0|                            .get(*field_index)
 1535|      0|                            .copied()
 1536|      0|                            .ok_or_else(|| format!("Field index {} out of bounds", field_index))?;
 1537|      0|                        (offset, true)
 1538|       |                    } else {
 1539|      0|                        return Err("Base of StructField is not a struct type".to_string());
 1540|       |                    }
 1541|       |                }
 1542|      0|                _ => return Err("Base of StructField is not a struct type".to_string()),
 1543|       |            };
 1544|       |

 1546|       |                // If the base is a pointer, we need to load the address it points to first
 1547|      0|                ctx.builder.ins().load(types::I64, MemFlags::new(), base_addr, 0)
 1548|       |            } else {
 1549|     23|                base_addr
 1550|       |            };

 1553|     23|            Ok(ctx.builder.ins().iadd(final_addr, offset_val))

 1575|      0|                    (size, loaded_ptr)

 1577|      0|                _ => return Err("Base of ArrayIndex is not an array or pointer".to_string()),
 1578|       |            };

 1581|     16|            let offset = ctx.builder.ins().imul(index_val, element_size_val);
 1582|       |

 1587|       |/// Helper to lower a single MIR statement
 1588|    150|fn lower_statement(stmt: &MirStmt, ctx: &mut BodyEmitContext) -> Result<(), String> {

 2785|     14|fn emit_cendol_set_al(module: &mut ObjectModule) -> Result<FuncId, String> {

 2788|     14|    sig.params.push(AbiParam::new(types::I64)); // addr
 2789|     14|    sig.returns.push(AbiParam::new(types::I64)); // count (RAX)
 2790|     14|    sig.returns.push(AbiParam::new(types::I64)); // addr (RDX)
 2791|       |

 2793|     14|        .declare_function("__cendol_set_al", Linkage::Export, &sig)
 2794|     14|        .map_err(|e| format!("Failed to declare __cendol_set_al: {:?}", e))?;
                                   ^0      ^0                                            ^0

 2797|     14|    ctx.func.signature = sig;

 2801|       |

 2804|     14|    builder.switch_to_block(block);
 2805|     14|    builder.seal_block(block);

/app/src/mir/dumper.rs:
    1|       |//! MIR (Mid-level Intermediate Representation) Dumper
    2|       |//!
    3|       |//! This module provides functionality to dump MIR in a human-readable format
    4|       |//! following the C11 compiler's specific conventions:
    5|       |//! - Local variables: %0, %1, %tmp3
    6|       |//! - Global variables: @g_var

    2|       |//!
    3|       |//! This module implements a validation pass that ensures MIR is well-formed
    4|       |//! and ready for code generation. The validation pass checks:

    6|       |//! - All blocks end with a Terminator

  161|       |    /// Validate that a constant value can be cast to the target type

  498|       |/// Parse abstract declarator (for type names without identifiers)

  500|     44|    debug!(
  501|      0|        "parse_abstract_declarator: starting at position {}, token {:?}",
  502|       |        parser.current_idx,

  535|      5|                    ParsedDeclarator::Abstract
  536|       |                }
  537|       |            }

  539|      0|                parser.advance(); // consume int

  542|      0|                    if let TokenKind::Identifier(name) = next_token.kind {
  543|      0|                        parser.advance(); // consume identifier

  545|       |                    } else {
  546|      0|                        ParsedDeclarator::Abstract

  586|      0|                        ParsedDeclarator::Function {

  589|      0|                            is_variadic: false,

  591|       |                    } else {

  462|    553|    pub fn tokenize_all(&mut self) -> Vec<Token> {
  463|       |        // Bolt : Pre-allocate the tokens vector with the capacity of the preprocessor tokens.
  464|       |        // This is a reasonable estimate that reduces the number of reallocations,
  465|       |        // as the number of lexical tokens is usually similar to the number of preprocessor tokens.
  466|    553|        let mut tokens = Vec::with_capacity(self.tokens.len());
  467|    553|        let mut current_token_iter = self.tokens.iter().peekable();
  468|       |
  469|  14.9k|        while let Some(pptoken) = current_token_iter.next() {

                                                            ^112

  472|       |                // This introduces a fast path for single string literals, which are the
  473|       |                // most common case. By peeking ahead, we avoid the overhead of the
  474|       |                // two-pass concatenation logic unless it's actually needed. This
  475|       |                // reduces overhead and improves lexer performance.
  476|       |

  478|    106|                if !matches!(
  479|    112|                    current_token_iter.peek(),

  486|    106|                        kind: self.classify_token(pptoken), // Handles quote stripping
  487|    106|                        span: SourceSpan::new_with_length(
  488|    106|                            pptoken.location.source_id(),
  489|    106|                            pptoken.location.offset(),
  490|    106|                            pptoken.length as u32,
  491|    106|                        ),
  492|    106|                    });
  493|    106|                    continue;
  494|      6|                }
  495|       |

  497|      6|                let start_span = SourceSpan::new_with_length(
  498|      6|                    pptoken.location.source_id(),
  499|      6|                    pptoken.location.offset(),
  500|      6|                    pptoken.length as u32,
  501|       |                );
  502|      6|                let mut final_span = start_span;
  503|       |
  504|       |                // --- Phase 1: Calculate total size and find last span ---
  505|      6|                let mut total_size = Self::extract_string_content(&symbol).unwrap_or("").len();
  506|      6|                let mut adjacent_literals = 0;
  507|      6|                let next_token_idx = self.tokens.len() - current_token_iter.len();
  508|       |

  510|     15|                    if let PPTokenKind::StringLiteral(next_symbol) = next_pptoken.kind {
                                                                    ^9

  513|      9|                            next_pptoken.location.source_id(),
  514|      9|                            next_pptoken.location.offset(),
  515|      9|                            next_pptoken.length as u32,
  516|      9|                        );

  518|      9|                    } else {
  519|      6|                        break;
  520|       |                    }
  521|       |                }
  522|       |

   79|       |                        // Usual arithmetic conversions
   80|      7|                        let is_unsigned = l.is_unsigned || r.is_unsigned;
                                                                         ^6
   81|      7|                        let l_val = l.value;
   82|      7|                        let r_val = r.value;
   83|       |
   84|      7|                        match op {
   85|      0|                            BinaryOp::BitOr => Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val | r_val, is_unsigned)),
   86|      0|                            BinaryOp::BitXor => Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val ^ r_val, is_unsigned)),
   87|      0|                            BinaryOp::BitAnd => Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val & r_val, is_unsigned)),
   88|      3|                            BinaryOp::Equal => Ok(ExprValue::from_bool(l_val == r_val)),
   89|      0|                            BinaryOp::NotEqual => Ok(ExprValue::from_bool(l_val != r_val)),
   90|       |                            BinaryOp::Less => {
   91|      1|                                if is_unsigned {
   92|      1|                                    Ok(ExprValue::from_bool(l_val < r_val))
   93|       |                                } else {
   94|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::from_bool((l_val as i64) < (r_val as i64)))
   95|       |                                }
   96|       |                            }
   97|       |                            BinaryOp::LessEqual => {
   98|      0|                                if is_unsigned {
   99|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::from_bool(l_val <= r_val))
  100|       |                                } else {
  101|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::from_bool((l_val as i64) <= (r_val as i64)))
  102|       |                                }
  103|       |                            }
  104|       |                            BinaryOp::Greater => {
  105|      1|                                if is_unsigned {
  106|      1|                                    Ok(ExprValue::from_bool(l_val > r_val))
  107|       |                                } else {
  108|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::from_bool((l_val as i64) > (r_val as i64)))
  109|       |                                }
  110|       |                            }
  111|       |                            BinaryOp::GreaterEqual => {
  112|      0|                                if is_unsigned {
  113|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::from_bool(l_val >= r_val))
  114|       |                                } else {
  115|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::from_bool((l_val as i64) >= (r_val as i64)))
  116|       |                                }
  117|       |                            }
  118|       |                            BinaryOp::LShift => {
  119|       |                                // Shift count is not subject to usual arithmetic conversions for type
  120|       |                                // But the result type is that of the promoted LHS.
  121|       |                                // We'll just use the promoted LHS type (integer promotion, but here we are already 64-bit).
  122|       |                                // C11: "The result has the type of the left operand."
  123|       |                                // So we preserve l.is_unsigned.
  124|      0|                                let shift_amount = r_val as u32;
  125|       |                                // Handle shift >= 64 behavior (UB in C, wrap in Rust)
  126|      0|                                if shift_amount >= 64 {
  127|       |                                    // UB, but zeroing is a common safe behavior or wrapping.
  128|       |                                    // Rust panics in debug on overflow, wrapping_shl masks.
  129|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val.wrapping_shl(shift_amount), l.is_unsigned))
  130|       |                                } else {
  131|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val << shift_amount, l.is_unsigned))
  132|       |                                }
  133|       |                            }
  134|       |                            BinaryOp::RShift => {
  135|      0|                                let shift_amount = r_val as u32;
  136|      0|                                if shift_amount >= 64 {
  137|       |                                    // UB
  138|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val.wrapping_shr(shift_amount), l.is_unsigned))
  139|      0|                                } else if l.is_unsigned {
  140|       |                                    // Logical shift
  141|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val >> shift_amount, true))
  142|       |                                } else {
  143|       |                                    // Arithmetic shift
  144|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::new(((l_val as i64) >> shift_amount) as u64, false))
  145|       |                                }
  146|       |                            }
  147|      1|                            BinaryOp::Add => Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val.wrapping_add(r_val), is_unsigned)),
  148|      0|                            BinaryOp::Sub => Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val.wrapping_sub(r_val), is_unsigned)),
  149|      1|                            BinaryOp::Mul => Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val.wrapping_mul(r_val), is_unsigned)),
  150|       |                            BinaryOp::Div => {
  151|      0|                                if r_val == 0 {
  152|      0|                                    Err(PPError::InvalidConditionalExpression)
  153|      0|                                } else if is_unsigned {
  154|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val / r_val, true))
  155|       |                                } else {
  156|       |                                    // Signed division
  157|       |                                    // Check for overflow: MIN / -1
  158|      0|                                    let l_signed = l_val as i64;
  159|      0|                                    let r_signed = r_val as i64;
  160|      0|                                    if l_signed == i64::MIN && r_signed == -1 {
  161|      0|                                        Ok(ExprValue::new(l_signed as u64, false)) // or overflow behavior
  162|       |                                    } else {
  163|      0|                                        Ok(ExprValue::new((l_signed / r_signed) as u64, false))
  164|       |                                    }
  165|       |                                }
  166|       |                            }
  167|       |                            BinaryOp::Mod => {
  168|      0|                                if r_val == 0 {
  169|      0|                                    Err(PPError::InvalidConditionalExpression)
  170|      0|                                } else if is_unsigned {
  171|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val % r_val, true))
  172|       |                                } else {
  173|      0|                                    let l_signed = l_val as i64;
  174|      0|                                    let r_signed = r_val as i64;
  175|      0|                                    if l_signed == i64::MIN && r_signed == -1 {
  176|      0|                                        Ok(ExprValue::new(0, false))
  177|       |                                    } else {
  178|      0|                                        Ok(ExprValue::new((l_signed % r_signed) as u64, false))
  179|       |                                    }
  180|       |                                }
  181|       |                            }
  182|      0|                            _ => unreachable!(),
  183|       |                        }
  184|       |                    }
  185|       |                }
  186|       |            }
  187|      1|            PPExpr::Unary(op, operand) => {
  188|      1|                let o = operand.evaluate(pp)?;
                                                          ^0
  189|      1|                match op {
  190|      0|                    UnaryOp::Plus => Ok(o),
  191|       |                    UnaryOp::Minus => {
  192|       |                        // Unsigned negation is 2's complement (wrapping_neg)
  193|      1|                        Ok(ExprValue::new(o.value.wrapping_neg(), o.is_unsigned))
  194|       |                    }
  195|      0|                    UnaryOp::BitNot => Ok(ExprValue::new(!o.value, o.is_unsigned)),
  196|      0|                    UnaryOp::LogicNot => Ok(ExprValue::from_bool(!o.is_truthy())),
  197|      0|                    _ => unreachable!("Unsupported unary operator in preprocessor"),
  198|       |                }
  199|       |            }
  200|      0|            PPExpr::Conditional(cond, true_e, false_e) => {
  201|      0|                let c = cond.evaluate(pp)?;
  202|      0|                let t = true_e.evaluate(pp)?;
  203|      0|                let f = false_e.evaluate(pp)?;
  204|       |
  205|      0|                if c.is_truthy() {
  206|       |                    // Result type depends on both operands usual arithmetic conversions
  207|       |                    // But we only return the evaluated one.
  208|       |                    // However, C11 says "the other operand is evaluated ... The result has the type..."
  209|       |                    // In an interpreter, we just return the value.
  210|       |                    // But if we wanted to be pedantic about type of the expression (e.g. for `sizeof`),
  211|       |                    // we would need to merge types.
  212|       |                    // But here we just return the value.
  213|       |                    // Wait, if I have `1 ? -1 : 0U`. Result should be unsigned.
  214|       |                    // `-1` converted to unsigned is MAX.
  215|       |                    // If we return `-1` as signed, and later compare it...
  216|       |                    // "The second and third operands are converted ... to the common type."
  217|      0|                    let is_unsigned = t.is_unsigned || f.is_unsigned;
  218|      0|                    if is_unsigned {
  219|      0|                        Ok(ExprValue::new(t.value, true))
  220|       |                    } else {
  221|      0|                        Ok(t)
  222|       |                    }
  223|       |                } else {
  224|      0|                    let is_unsigned = t.is_unsigned || f.is_unsigned;
  225|      0|                    if is_unsigned {
  226|      0|                        Ok(ExprValue::new(f.value, true))
  227|       |                    } else {
  228|      0|                        Ok(f)
  229|       |                    }
  230|       |                }
  231|       |            }
  232|       |        }
  233|     51|    }
  234|       |}

  336|       |    ///  Bolt: Consolidated operator lexing.

  338|       |    /// significantly reducing code duplication and branching in the main `next_token` function.
  339|       |    /// This improves performance by making the tokenization logic more direct and predictable
  340|       |    /// for the compiler to optimize. It also fixes a bug in the original `...` lexing logic.
  341|  8.40k|    fn lex_operator(&mut self, start_pos: u32, ch: u8, flags: PPTokenFlags) -> PPToken {

  355|       |        }

  757|       |    /// Consumes characters based on a predicate, building a string.

  759|       |    /// The predicate receives the current state and the character.

  776|  2.52k|                    if pred(&mut state, ch) {
  777|  1.47k|                        self.position += 1;

  779|  1.47k|                        continue;
  780|       |                    } else {
  781|  1.04k|                        break;
  782|       |                    }

  784|     44|            }
  785|       |
  786|     45|            if let Some(ch) = self.peek_char()
                                      ^1
  787|      1|                && pred(&mut state, ch)
  788|       |            {
  789|      1|                chars.push(self.next_char().unwrap());
  790|      1|                continue;
  791|     44|            }
  792|     44|            break;
  793|       |        }
  794|       |        // Safety: We assume the caller only consumes valid UTF-8 characters (identifiers/numbers).
  795|  1.09k|        String::from_utf8(chars).unwrap()

  798|       |    /// Generic helper for lexing textual tokens (identifiers, numbers)

  821|       |
  822|       |    /// Try to parse a UCN.
  823|       |    /// Assumes the leading backslash has already been consumed.
  824|       |    /// Returns:
  825|       |    /// - None: Not a UCN (didn't consume anything).
  826|       |    /// - Some(Ok((char, raw_string))): Valid UCN.
  827|       |    /// - Some(Err(raw_string)): Invalid UCN (consumed raw_string).
  828|     40|    fn lex_ucn(&mut self, allow_basic_charset: bool) -> Option<Result<(char, String), String>> {
  829|     40|        let is_u = match self.peek_char() {
                          ^5
  830|      5|            Some(b'u') => true,
  831|      0|            Some(b'U') => false,
  832|     35|            _ => return None,
  833|       |        };
  834|       |
  835|      5|        self.next_char(); // Consume u/U
  836|       |
  837|      5|        let digits_needed = if is_u { 4 } else { 8 };
                                                               ^0
  838|      5|        let mut hex_str = String::new();
  839|       |
  840|      5|        for _ in 0..digits_needed {
  841|     20|            if let Some(ch) = self.peek_char() {
  842|     20|                if ch.is_ascii_hexdigit() {
  843|     20|                    self.next_char();
  844|     20|                    hex_str.push(ch as char);
  845|     20|                } else {
  846|      0|                    break;
  847|       |                }
  848|       |            } else {
  849|      0|                break;
  850|       |            }
  851|       |        }
  852|       |
  853|      5|        let prefix = if is_u { "\\u" } else { "\\U" };
                                                            ^0
  854|      5|        let raw_string = format!("{}{}", prefix, hex_str);
  855|       |
  856|      5|        if hex_str.len() != digits_needed {
  857|      0|            return Some(Err(raw_string));
  858|      5|        }
  859|       |
  860|      5|        let code_point = u32::from_str_radix(&hex_str, 16).unwrap();
  861|       |
  862|       |        // Validation
  863|       |        // 1. Range
  864|      5|        if code_point > 0x10FFFF {

  572|     49|    fn tokens_to_path_string(&self, tokens: &[PPToken]) -> String {

  574|       |        // This avoids multiple reallocations from push_str in a loop, a known
  575|       |        // performance anti-pattern in this codebase.
  576|       |        // 1. Calculate the total length of the path.
  577|    165|        let total_len = tokens.iter().map(|part| part.length as usize).sum();
                          ^49         ^49    ^49    ^49                              ^49
  578|       |
  579|       |        // 2. Allocate the string with the exact capacity.
  580|     49|        let mut path = String::with_capacity(total_len);
  581|       |
  582|       |        // 3. Populate the string.
  583|    165|        for part in tokens.iter() {
                                  ^49    ^49
  584|    165|            let buffer = self.sm.get_buffer(part.location.source_id());
  585|    165|            let start = part.location.offset() as usize;
  586|    165|            let end = start + part.length as usize;
  587|    165|            if end <= buffer.len() {
  588|    165|                let text = unsafe { std::str::from_utf8_unchecked(&buffer[start..end]) };
  589|    165|                path.push_str(text);
  590|    165|            }
                          ^0
  591|       |        }
  592|     49|        path
  593|     49|    }

 1746|      1|    fn consume_rest_of_line_as_string(&mut self) -> String {
 1747|       |        // Optimization: Avoid multiple small allocations by calculating final string size first.
 1748|       |        // This follows the two-pass approach:
 1749|       |        // 1. Collect tokens for the line.
 1750|       |        // 2. Calculate the total length required for the string.
 1751|       |        // 3. Allocate a single string with the required capacity.
 1752|       |        // 4. Populate the string in a second pass over the tokens.
 1753|      1|        let mut tokens = Vec::new();
 1754|      2|        while let Some(token) = self.lex_token() {
 1755|      2|            if token.kind == PPTokenKind::Eod {
 1756|      1|                break;
 1757|      1|            }
 1758|      1|            tokens.push(token);
 1759|       |        }
 1760|       |
 1761|      1|        if tokens.is_empty() {
 1762|      0|            return String::new();
 1763|      1|        }
 1764|       |
 1765|       |        // Calculate total length
 1766|      1|        let mut total_len = 0;
 1767|      1|        for (i, token) in tokens.iter().enumerate() {
 1768|      1|            total_len += token.length as usize;
 1769|      1|            if i > 0 {
 1770|      0|                total_len += 1; // For the space separator
 1771|      1|            }
 1772|       |        }
 1773|       |
 1774|       |        // Allocate and build the string
 1775|      1|        let mut result = String::with_capacity(total_len);
 1776|      1|        for (i, token) in tokens.iter().enumerate() {
 1777|      1|            if i > 0 {
 1778|      0|                result.push(' ');
 1779|      1|            }
 1780|      1|            let buffer = self.sm.get_buffer(token.location.source_id());
 1781|      1|            let start = token.location.offset() as usize;
 1782|      1|            let end = start + token.length as usize;
 1783|      1|            if end <= buffer.len() {
 1784|      1|                // This is safe because the lexer guarantees tokens are valid UTF-8.
 1785|      1|                let text = unsafe { std::str::from_utf8_unchecked(&buffer[start..end]) };
 1786|      1|                result.push_str(text);
 1787|      1|            }
                          ^0
 1788|       |        }
 1789|       |
 1790|      1|        result
 1791|      1|    }

 2076|       |    /// Stringify tokens for # operator
 2077|      4|    pub(crate) fn stringify_tokens(&self, tokens: &[PPToken], location: SourceLoc) -> Result<PPToken, PPError> {
 2078|       |        // Bolt : Use a two-pass approach to build the stringified token efficiently.
 2079|       |        // This avoids multiple reallocations from push/push_str in a loop.
 2080|       |        // 1. Calculate the final length of the string, accounting for escaped characters.

 2090|      0|                return Err(PPError::InvalidStringification);

 2094|       |            // Iterating over bytes is faster than UTF-8 chars and correctly calculates
 2095|       |            // the required byte capacity for multi-byte characters.

 2107|      4|        result.push('"');
 2108|       |

 2130|      1|                            result.push_str("\\\"");

  725|    211|    fn check_assignment_constraints(&self, lhs_ty: QualType, rhs_ty: QualType, rhs_ref: NodeRef) -> bool {
  726|       |        // 1. Arithmetic types
  727|    211|        if lhs_ty.is_arithmetic() && rhs_ty.is_arithmetic() {
                                                   ^166   ^166
  728|    161|            return true;
  729|     50|        }
  730|       |
  731|       |        // 2. Structure or Union types
  732|     50|        if lhs_ty.is_record() || rhs_ty.is_record() {
                                               ^42    ^42
  733|      9|            return lhs_ty.is_record() && rhs_ty.is_record() && lhs_ty.ty() == rhs_ty.ty();
                                                       ^8     ^8             ^7
  734|     41|        }
  735|       |
  736|       |        // 3. Pointers
  737|     41|        if lhs_ty.is_pointer() {

  739|      4|                return true;
  740|     33|            }
  741|       |

  546|     10|            }

  604|      1|    fn lower_switch_statement(&mut self, cond: NodeRef, body: NodeRef) {
  605|      1|        let cond_op = self.lower_expression(cond, true);
  606|       |
  607|       |        // Integer promotions on controlling expression are handled by lower_expression if sema did it?
  608|       |        // Semantic analysis should have inserted implicit conversions.
  609|       |        // But we might need to cast case values to this type.
  610|      1|        let cond_ty_id = self.get_operand_type(&cond_op);
  611|       |
  612|      1|        let merge_block = self.mir_builder.create_block();
  613|       |
  614|      1|        let saved_break = self.break_target;
  615|      1|        self.break_target = Some(merge_block);
  616|       |
  617|       |        // Collect cases
  618|      1|        let cases = self.collect_switch_cases(body);
  619|       |
  620|       |        // Create blocks for cases
  621|      1|        let mut case_blocks = Vec::new();
  622|      1|        let mut default_block = None;
  623|       |
  624|      4|        for (node, val_opt) in cases {

  625|      3|            let block = self.mir_builder.create_block();
  626|      3|            self.switch_case_map.insert(node, block);
  627|       |
  628|      3|            if let Some(val) = val_opt {

  629|      2|                case_blocks.push((val, block));
  630|      2|            } else {
  631|      1|                default_block = Some(block);
  632|      1|            }
  633|       |        }
  634|       |
  635|       |        // Generate dispatch
  636|      1|        let fallback_block = default_block.unwrap_or(merge_block);
  637|       |
  638|      3|        for (val_id, target_block) in case_blocks {
                           ^2      ^2
  639|      2|            let next_test_block = self.mir_builder.create_block();
  640|      2|            let val_const = self.mir_builder.get_constants().get(&val_id).unwrap().clone();
  641|       |
  642|       |            // Re-create constant with the same type as condition to ensure safe comparison
  643|       |            // This assumes the values are compatible (integral).
  644|       |            // Sema should ensure they are compatible.
  645|       |            // We just cast the constant value to the condition type for the comparison operand.
  646|       |            // Note: `val_const` is already lowered to some type.
  647|       |
  648|      2|            let val_op = Operand::Constant(val_id);
  649|      2|            let cast_val_op = if val_const.ty != cond_ty_id {
  650|      0|                Operand::Cast(cond_ty_id, Box::new(val_op))
  651|       |            } else {
  652|      2|                val_op
  653|       |            };
  654|       |
  655|       |            // Use Eq comparison
  656|       |            // If condition is float (illegal in C switch), we panic?
  657|       |            // Switch only works on integers.
  658|      2|            let cmp_rvalue = Rvalue::BinaryIntOp(BinaryIntOp::Eq, cond_op.clone(), cast_val_op);
  659|      2|            let bool_type_id = self.lower_type(self.registry.type_bool);
  660|      2|            let (_cmp_local, cmp_place) = self.create_temp_local_with_assignment(cmp_rvalue, bool_type_id);
  661|      2|            let cmp_op = Operand::Copy(Box::new(cmp_place));
  662|       |
  663|      2|            self.mir_builder
  664|      2|                .set_terminator(Terminator::If(cmp_op, target_block, next_test_block));
  665|       |
  666|      2|            self.mir_builder.set_current_block(next_test_block);
  667|      2|            self.current_block = Some(next_test_block);
  668|       |        }

  672|       |

  674|       |        // Start a dummy unreachable block for the body entry (to catch unreachable statements)
  675|      1|        let body_entry_dummy = self.mir_builder.create_block();
  676|       |        // Do not jump to it. It is unreachable.
  677|       |
  678|      1|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(body_entry_dummy);

  684|      1|        if self.mir_builder.current_block_has_terminator() == false {
  685|      0|            // Check if terminator is Unreachable (default) - if so, we can replace it or just leave it?
  686|      0|            // `current_block_has_terminator` returns false if it is Unreachable.

  688|      0|            // Actually, if execution falls through the body, it should hit merge.

  692|       |
  693|      1|        self.break_target = saved_break;

  695|      1|        self.current_block = Some(merge_block);
  696|      1|    }

    2|       |//!
    3|       |//! This module provides the functionality to evaluate constant expressions
    4|       |//! at compile time, as required by the C11 standard for contexts like
    5|       |//! static assertions and array sizes.

   10|       |/// Context for constant expression evaluation
   11|       |pub(crate) struct ConstEvalCtx<'a> {
   12|       |    pub(crate) ast: &'a Ast,
   13|       |    pub(crate) symbol_table: &'a SymbolTable,
   14|       |    pub(crate) registry: &'a TypeRegistry,
   15|       |    pub(crate) semantic_info: Option<&'a SemanticInfo>,
   16|       |}

   18|       |/// Evaluate a constant expression node to an i64 value
   19|    456|pub(crate) fn eval_const_expr(ctx: &ConstEvalCtx, expr_node_ref: NodeRef) -> Option<i64> {
   20|    456|    let node_kind = ctx.ast.get_kind(expr_node_ref);
   21|    142|    match node_kind {
   22|    142|        NodeKind::Literal(literal::Literal::Int { val, .. }) => Some(*val),
   23|      0|        NodeKind::Literal(literal::Literal::Char(val)) => Some(*val as i64),
   24|     68|        NodeKind::Ident(_, sym_ref) => {

   26|     68|            if let SymbolKind::EnumConstant { value } = &symbol.kind {
                                                            ^4
   27|      4|                Some(*value)
   28|       |            } else {
   29|     64|                None
   30|       |            }
   31|       |        }
   32|    110|        NodeKind::BinaryOp(op, left_ref, right_ref) => {
   33|    110|            let left_val = eval_const_expr(ctx, *left_ref)?;
                              ^37                                       ^73
   34|     37|            let right_val = eval_const_expr(ctx, *right_ref)?;
                              ^36                                         ^1
   35|     36|            match op {
   36|      2|                BinaryOp::Add => Some(left_val.wrapping_add(right_val)),
   37|      2|                BinaryOp::Sub => Some(left_val.wrapping_sub(right_val)),
   38|      2|                BinaryOp::Mul => Some(left_val.wrapping_mul(right_val)),
   39|       |                BinaryOp::Div => {
   40|      0|                    if right_val != 0 {
   41|      0|                        Some(left_val.wrapping_div(right_val))
   42|       |                    } else {
   43|      0|                        None
   44|       |                    }
   45|       |                }
   46|      8|                BinaryOp::Equal => Some((left_val == right_val) as i64),
   47|     10|                BinaryOp::NotEqual => Some((left_val != right_val) as i64),
   48|      6|                BinaryOp::Less => Some((left_val < right_val) as i64),
   49|      1|                BinaryOp::LessEqual => Some((left_val <= right_val) as i64),
   50|      1|                BinaryOp::Greater => Some((left_val > right_val) as i64),
   51|      1|                BinaryOp::GreaterEqual => Some((left_val >= right_val) as i64),
   52|      1|                BinaryOp::LogicAnd => Some(((left_val != 0) && (right_val != 0)) as i64),
   53|      2|                BinaryOp::LogicOr => Some(((left_val != 0) || (right_val != 0)) as i64),
                                                                            ^1

   56|      0|                BinaryOp::BitXor => Some(left_val ^ right_val),

    6|       |/// Performs the "usual arithmetic conversions" as specified in C11 6.3.1.8.
    7|     92|pub(crate) fn usual_arithmetic_conversions(ctx: &TypeRegistry, lhs: QualType, rhs: QualType) -> Option<QualType> {
    8|     92|    let lb = lhs.ty().builtin()?;
                                             ^0
    9|     92|    let rb = rhs.ty().builtin()?;
                                             ^0
   10|       |
   11|       |    // Floating point conversions: long double > double > float
   12|     92|    if lb.is_floating() || rb.is_floating() {
   13|      0|        let common = match (lb, rb) {
   14|      0|            (BuiltinType::LongDouble, _) | (_, BuiltinType::LongDouble) => ctx.type_long_double,
   15|      0|            (BuiltinType::Double, _) | (_, BuiltinType::Double) => ctx.type_double,
   16|      0|            _ => ctx.type_float,
   17|       |        };
   18|      0|        return Some(QualType::unqualified(common));
   19|     92|    }
   20|       |
   21|       |    // Both types are promoted to at least 'int' or 'unsigned int'
   22|     92|    let lp = integer_promotion(ctx, lhs);
   23|     92|    let rp = integer_promotion(ctx, rhs);
   24|     92|    if lp == rp {
   25|     69|        return Some(lp);
   26|     23|    }
   27|       |
   28|     23|    let lbp = lp.ty().builtin()?;
                                             ^0
   29|     23|    let rbp = rp.ty().builtin()?;
                                             ^0
   30|     23|    let (ls, lr) = (lbp.is_signed(), lbp.rank());
   31|     23|    let (rs, rr) = (rbp.is_signed(), rbp.rank());
   32|       |
   33|       |    // Same signedness: higher rank wins
   34|     23|    if ls == rs {
   35|      4|        return Some(if lr >= rr { lp } else { rp });

   36|     19|    }
   37|       |
   38|       |    // Different signedness: Higher rank usually wins; if ranks are equal, unsigned wins.
   39|     19|    let (ut, ur, st, sr) = if ls { (rp, rr, lp, lr) } else { (lp, lr, rp, rr) };
                                                 ^1^1  ^1                   ^18^18 ^18
   40|     19|    if ur >= sr {
   41|     18|        Some(ut)
   42|       |    } else {
   43|       |        // If the signed type can represent all values of the unsigned type, it wins.
   44|       |        // For currently supported targets (e.g. 32-bit int, 64-bit long), this holds.
   45|      1|        Some(st)
   46|       |    }
   47|     92|}

  374|     58|    pub(crate) fn lower_binary_op_expr(

  438|      4|    pub(crate) fn emit_bool_normalization(
  439|      4|        &mut self,
  440|      4|        value_op: Operand,
  441|      4|        result_place: Place,
  442|      4|        merge_block: crate::mir::MirBlockId,
  443|      4|    ) {
  444|      4|        let true_block = self.mir_builder.create_block();
  445|      4|        let false_block = self.mir_builder.create_block();
  446|       |
  447|      4|        self.mir_builder
  448|      4|            .set_terminator(Terminator::If(value_op, true_block, false_block));
  449|       |
  450|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(true_block);
  451|      4|        let one_op = self.create_int_operand(1);
  452|      4|        self.mir_builder
  453|      4|            .add_statement(MirStmt::Assign(result_place.clone(), Rvalue::Use(one_op)));
  454|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_terminator(Terminator::Goto(merge_block));
  455|       |
  456|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(false_block);
  457|      4|        let zero_op = self.create_int_operand(0);
  458|      4|        self.mir_builder
  459|      4|            .add_statement(MirStmt::Assign(result_place.clone(), Rvalue::Use(zero_op)));
  460|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_terminator(Terminator::Goto(merge_block));
  461|      4|    }

  463|      4|    pub(crate) fn lower_logical_op(
  464|      4|        &mut self,
  465|      4|        op: &BinaryOp,
  466|      4|        left_ref: NodeRef,
  467|      4|        right_ref: NodeRef,
  468|      4|        mir_ty: TypeId,
  469|      4|    ) -> Operand {
  470|       |        // Short-circuiting logic for && and ||
  471|      4|        let (_res_local, res_place) = self.create_temp_local(mir_ty);
  472|       |
  473|      4|        let eval_rhs_block = self.mir_builder.create_block();
  474|      4|        let merge_block = self.mir_builder.create_block();
  475|      4|        let short_circuit_block = self.mir_builder.create_block();
  476|       |
  477|       |        // 1. Evaluate LHS
  478|      4|        let lhs_op = self.lower_condition(left_ref);
  479|       |
  480|       |        // Pre-create constants to avoid double borrow
  481|      4|        let zero_op = self.create_int_operand(0);
  482|      4|        let one_op = self.create_int_operand(1);
  483|       |
  484|      4|        let (short_circuit_val, true_target, false_target) = match op {
  485|      0|            BinaryOp::LogicAnd => (zero_op.clone(), eval_rhs_block, short_circuit_block),
  486|      4|            BinaryOp::LogicOr => (one_op.clone(), short_circuit_block, eval_rhs_block),
  487|      0|            _ => unreachable!(),
  488|       |        };
  489|       |
  490|       |        // if lhs { goto true_target } else { goto false_target }
  491|      4|        self.mir_builder
  492|      4|            .set_terminator(Terminator::If(lhs_op, true_target, false_target));
  493|       |
  494|       |        // Short circuit case
  495|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(short_circuit_block);
  496|      4|        self.mir_builder
  497|      4|            .add_statement(MirStmt::Assign(res_place.clone(), Rvalue::Use(short_circuit_val)));
  498|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_terminator(Terminator::Goto(merge_block));
  499|       |
  500|       |        // 2. Evaluate RHS
  501|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(eval_rhs_block);
  502|      4|        let rhs_val = self.lower_condition(right_ref);
  503|       |
  504|      4|        self.emit_bool_normalization(rhs_val, res_place.clone(), merge_block);
  505|       |
  506|       |        // Merge
  507|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(merge_block);
  508|      4|        self.current_block = Some(merge_block);
  509|       |
  510|      4|        Operand::Copy(Box::new(res_place))
  511|      4|    }

  848|     15|    pub(crate) fn create_inc_dec_rvalue(&mut self, operand: Operand, operand_ty: QualType, is_inc: bool) -> Rvalue {

  768|       |/// Merge base types according to C type combination rules
  769|  2.15k|fn merge_base_type(
  770|  2.15k|    existing: Option<QualType>,
  771|  2.15k|    new_type: QualType,
  772|  2.15k|    ctx: &mut LowerCtx,
  773|  2.15k|    span: SourceSpan,

  775|  2.15k|    match existing {
  776|  1.84k|        None => Some(new_type),

  778|    315|            let existing_type = ctx.registry.get(existing_ref.ty());

  780|       |
  781|    315|            match (&existing_type.kind, &new_type_info.kind) {

  783|    315|                    match (existing_builtin, new_builtin) {

  785|    315|                        (a, b) if a == b => {

  789|       |                            // EXCEPT for types that already have a combined form (like long long).
  790|      1|                            if *a == BuiltinType::Long {

  479|       |    /// Merge a new symbol entry with an existing one in the global scope.
  480|       |    /// This implements C11 6.9.2 for handling tentative definitions, extern declarations, and actual definitions.
  481|    598|    fn merge_global_symbol(&mut self, name: NameId, mut new_entry: Symbol) -> Result<SymbolRef, SymbolTableError> {
  482|    598|        let global_scope = ScopeId::GLOBAL;
  483|       |
  484|       |        // Check if symbol already exists in global scope
  485|    598|        if let Some(existing_ref) = self.fetch(name, global_scope, Namespace::Ordinary) {
                                  ^23
  486|     23|            let existing = self.get_symbol_mut(existing_ref);
  487|       |
  488|       |            // Verify kinds match
  489|     23|            match (&existing.kind, &new_entry.kind) {
  490|      5|                (SymbolKind::Variable { .. }, SymbolKind::Variable { .. }) => {}
  491|     16|                (SymbolKind::Function { .. }, SymbolKind::Function { .. }) => {}
  492|       |                _ => {
  493|       |                    // Mismatched kinds
  494|      2|                    debug!("Symbol '{}' redefinition: different kinds", name);
                                         ^0
  495|      2|                    return Err(SymbolTableError::InvalidRedefinition {
  496|      2|                        name,
  497|      2|                        existing: existing_ref,
  498|      2|                    });
  499|       |                }
  500|       |            }
  501|       |
  502|       |            // Check alignment compatibility (Variables only)
  503|       |            if let SymbolKind::Variable {
  504|      5|                alignment: new_align, ..
  505|     21|            } = &new_entry.kind
  506|       |                && let SymbolKind::Variable {
  507|      5|                    alignment: existing_align,
  508|       |                    ..
  509|      5|                } = &existing.kind
  510|       |            {
  511|      5|                match (existing_align, new_align) {
  512|      0|                    (Some(a), Some(b)) if a != b => {
  513|      0|                        return Err(SymbolTableError::InvalidRedefinition {
  514|      0|                            name,
  515|      0|                            existing: existing_ref,
  516|      0|                        });
  517|       |                    }
  518|      0|                    (None, Some(b)) => {
  519|       |                        // Inherit alignment from new declaration
  520|      0|                        if let SymbolKind::Variable { alignment, .. } = &mut existing.kind {
  521|      0|                            *alignment = Some(*b);
  522|      0|                        }
  523|       |                    }
  524|      5|                    _ => {}
  525|       |                }
  526|     16|            }
  527|       |
  528|       |            // Apply C11 merging rules
  529|     21|            match (existing.def_state, new_entry.def_state) {
  530|       |                (DefinitionState::Defined, DefinitionState::Defined) => {
  531|       |                    // Multiple actual definitions - error
  532|      2|                    debug!("Multiple definitions of '{}'", name);

  533|      2|                    return Err(SymbolTableError::InvalidRedefinition {
  534|      2|                        name,
  535|      2|                        existing: existing_ref,
  536|      2|                    });

  539|       |                (DefinitionState::Defined, _) => {

  541|      1|                    debug!("Ignoring redundant declaration for already-defined '{}'", name);

  546|     10|                    debug!("Upgrading to defined for '{}'", name);

  711|     77|    fn compute_record_layout(&mut self, members: &[StructMember], is_union: bool) -> Result<TypeLayout, SemanticError> {
  712|     77|        let mut max_align = 1;
  713|     77|        let mut current_size = 0;
  714|     77|        let mut field_layouts = Vec::with_capacity(members.len());
  715|       |        // For C11 6.7.2.1p18 flexible array check:
  716|       |        // "the last element of a structure with more than one named member may have an incomplete array type"
  717|       |        // But incomplete array types are NOT allowed in unions.
  718|       |        // We will check validity as we iterate.
  719|       |        // Note: The count of members might include anonymous struct/union members which are technically members.
  720|       |
  721|     77|        let member_count = members.len();
  722|       |
  723|    132|        for (i, member) in members.iter().enumerate() {
                                         ^77     ^77    ^77
  724|    132|            let member_ty = member.member_type.ty();
  725|       |
  726|       |            // Special handling for flexible array member (FAM)
  727|       |            // Need to check if it is incomplete array
  728|       |            // We can't use is_complete because that recurses. We check TypeKind directly.
  729|    132|            let is_incomplete_or_vla_array = if member_ty.is_inline_array() {
  730|      5|                false // inline array always has len
  731|       |            } else {
  732|    124|                matches!(
  733|    127|                    self.get(member_ty).kind,
  734|       |                    TypeKind::Array {
  735|       |                        size: ArraySizeType::Incomplete | ArraySizeType::Variable(_),
  736|       |                        ..
  737|       |                    }
  738|       |                )
  739|       |            };
  740|       |
  741|    132|            if is_incomplete_or_vla_array {
  742|      3|                if is_union {
  743|       |                    // Incomplete or VLA types not allowed in union
  744|      1|                    return Err(SemanticError::UnsupportedFeature {
  745|      1|                        feature: "incomplete/VLA array in union".to_string(),
  746|      1|                        span: member.span,
  747|      1|                    });
  748|      2|                }
  749|       |
  750|       |                // Must be last member
  751|      2|                if i != member_count - 1 {
  752|      1|                    return Err(SemanticError::FlexibleArrayNotLast { span: member.span });
  753|      1|                }
  754|       |
  755|       |                // Must have at least one other named member.
  756|       |                // Or rather, "structure with more than one named member".
  757|       |                // If this is the only member, it's invalid.
  758|      1|                if member_count < 2 {
  759|      0|                    return Err(SemanticError::FlexibleArrayInEmptyStruct { span: member.span });
  760|      1|                }
  761|       |
  762|       |                // If valid FAM:
  763|       |                // Size of structure is as if FAM was omitted.
  764|       |                // But we must respect its alignment for the struct's alignment.
  765|       |                // We need to get the element type to find alignment.
  766|      1|                let elem_ty = match &self.get(member_ty).kind {
  767|      1|                    TypeKind::Array { element_type, .. } => *element_type,
  768|      0|                    _ => unreachable!(),
  769|       |                };
  770|      1|                let elem_layout = self.ensure_layout(elem_ty)?;
                                                                           ^0
  771|       |
  772|      1|                max_align = max_align.max(elem_layout.alignment);
  773|       |
  774|       |                // FAM has size 0 for layout purposes of the struct size,
  775|       |                // but its offset is where it would start.
  776|       |                // The standard says: "size of the structure is as if the flexible array member were omitted"
  777|       |                // This means current_size stays as is (after padding for alignment of FAM? No, omitted means omitted).
  778|       |                // "except that it may have more trailing padding than the omission would imply"
  779|       |                // Usually this is interpreted as: sizeof(struct) = max(sizeof(struct_without_fam), offsetof(fam)).
  780|       |                // Or simply: layout the FAM, but don't increment current_size by its size (which is unknown/0).
  781|       |                // But we might need to add padding to current_size to reach FAM alignment?
  782|       |                // "as if the flexible array member were omitted" implies we don't even add padding for it?
  783|       |                // BUT "except that it may have more trailing padding".
  784|       |                // Most compilers align the end of the struct to the alignment of the FAM.
  785|       |
  786|       |                // Let's compute offset.
  787|      1|                let offset = (current_size + elem_layout.alignment - 1) & !(elem_layout.alignment - 1);
  788|      1|                field_layouts.push(FieldLayout { offset });
  789|       |
  790|       |                // We do NOT update current_size with FAM size (which is effectively 0 or variable).
  791|       |                // But we might update current_size to offset?
  792|       |                // GCC: sizeof(struct { int x; int y[]; }) == 4.
  793|       |                //      sizeof(struct { char c; int y[]; }) == 4 (aligned to 4).
  794|       |                // So we do align current_size.
  795|      1|                current_size = offset;
  796|       |
  797|      1|                continue;
  798|    129|            }
  799|       |
  800|    129|            let layout = self.ensure_layout(member_ty)?;
                              ^128                                  ^1
  801|    128|            let mut member_align = layout.alignment;
  802|    128|            if let Some(req_align) = member.alignment {
                                      ^4
  803|      4|                member_align = member_align.max(req_align as u16);
  804|    124|            }
  805|    128|            max_align = max_align.max(member_align);
  806|       |
  807|    128|            if is_union {
  808|     13|                current_size = current_size.max(layout.size);
  809|     13|                field_layouts.push(FieldLayout { offset: 0 });
  810|    115|            } else {
  811|    115|                // Align current_size to member's alignment to find its offset
  812|    115|                let offset = (current_size + member_align - 1) & !(member_align - 1);
  813|    115|                field_layouts.push(FieldLayout { offset });
  814|    115|                current_size = offset + layout.size;
  815|    115|            }
  816|       |        }
  817|       |
  818|       |        // Final size is padded to the record's max alignment
  819|     74|        let final_size = (current_size + max_align - 1) & !(max_align - 1);
  820|       |
  821|     74|        Ok(TypeLayout {
  822|     74|            size: final_size,
  823|     74|            alignment: max_align,
  824|     74|            kind: LayoutKind::Record {
  825|     74|                fields: field_layouts,
  826|     74|                is_union,
  827|     74|            },
  828|     74|        })
  829|     77|    }

  831|    530|    pub(crate) fn decay(&mut self, qt: QualType, ptr_qualifiers: TypeQualifiers) -> QualType {
  832|    530|        let kind = self.get(qt.ty()).kind.clone();
  833|    530|        match kind {
  834|     54|            TypeKind::Array { element_type, .. } => {
  835|       |                // Correct logic: Array of T decays to Pointer to T.
  836|       |                // Qualifiers on Array apply to the element in the resulting pointer type.
  837|     54|                let elem_qt = QualType::new(element_type, qt.qualifiers());
  838|     54|                let ptr = self.pointer_to(elem_qt);
  839|       |                // Apply the extracted pointer qualifiers (e.g. from static/const inside [])
  840|     54|                QualType::new(ptr, ptr_qualifiers)
  841|       |            }
  842|       |            TypeKind::Function { .. } => {
  843|     10|                let ptr = self.pointer_to(qt);
  844|     10|                QualType::new(ptr, ptr_qualifiers)
  845|       |            }
  846|    466|            _ => qt,
  847|       |        }
  848|    530|    }

  858|     76|    pub(crate) fn is_compatible(&self, a: QualType, b: QualType) -> bool {
  859|     76|        if a == b {
  860|     59|            return true;
  861|     17|        }
  862|       |
  863|     17|        if a.qualifiers() != b.qualifiers() {
  864|      1|            return false;
  865|     16|        }
  866|       |
  867|     16|        let ty_a_ref = a.ty();
  868|     16|        let ty_b_ref = b.ty();
  869|       |
  870|     16|        if ty_a_ref == ty_b_ref {
  871|      0|            return true;
  872|     16|        }
  873|       |
  874|     16|        let kind_a = self.get(ty_a_ref).kind.clone();
  875|     16|        let kind_b = self.get(ty_b_ref).kind.clone();
  876|       |
  877|     16|        match (kind_a, kind_b) {
  878|       |            (
  879|       |                TypeKind::Array {
  880|      0|                    element_type: elem_a,
  881|      0|                    size: size_a,
  882|       |                },
  883|       |                TypeKind::Array {
  884|      0|                    element_type: elem_b,
  885|      0|                    size: size_b,
  886|       |                },
  887|       |            ) => {
  888|      0|                if !self.is_compatible(QualType::unqualified(elem_a), QualType::unqualified(elem_b)) {
  889|      0|                    return false;
  890|      0|                }
  891|      0|                match (size_a, size_b) {
  892|      0|                    (ArraySizeType::Incomplete, _) => true,
  893|      0|                    (_, ArraySizeType::Incomplete) => true,
  894|      0|                    (ArraySizeType::Constant(sa), ArraySizeType::Constant(sb)) => sa == sb,
  895|      0|                    (ArraySizeType::Star, _) => true,
  896|      0|                    (_, ArraySizeType::Star) => true,
  897|      0|                    _ => false,
  898|       |                }
  899|       |            }
  900|       |            (
  901|       |                TypeKind::Function {
  902|      4|                    return_type: ret_a,
  903|      4|                    parameters: params_a,
  904|      4|                    is_variadic: var_a,
  905|       |                    ..
  906|       |                },
  907|       |                TypeKind::Function {
  908|      4|                    return_type: ret_b,
  909|      4|                    parameters: params_b,
  910|      4|                    is_variadic: var_b,
  911|       |                    ..
  912|       |                },
  913|       |            ) => {
  914|      4|                if var_a != var_b {

  916|      4|                }

  918|      0|                    return false;
  919|      4|                }
  920|      4|                if params_a.len() != params_b.len() {
  921|      0|                    return false;
  922|      4|                }
  923|      4|                for (p_a, p_b) in params_a.iter().zip(params_b.iter()) {
                                   ^3   ^3

  925|      3|                    let type_a = QualType::unqualified(p_a.param_type.ty());
  926|      3|                    let type_b = QualType::unqualified(p_b.param_type.ty());
  927|      3|                    if !self.is_compatible(type_a, type_b) {
  928|      2|                        return false;
  929|      1|                    }
  930|       |                }

  226|       |/// Opaque reference to a canonical type.
  227|       |/// Internally index + 1 (NonZeroU32 for niche optimization).
  228|       |#[derive(Copy, Clone, Debug, PartialEq, Eq, Hash, Serialize)]
  229|       |#[repr(transparent)]
  230|       |pub struct TypeRef(NonZeroU32);
  231|       |
  232|       |impl TypeRef {
  233|       |    // Layout:
  234|       |    // bit  0..=17  (18 bit)  BASE INDEX
  235|       |    // bit 18..=20  (3 bit)   TYPE CLASS
  236|       |    // bit 21..=22  (2 bit)   POINTER DEPTH (0..3)
  237|       |    // bit 23..=27  (5 bit)   ARRAY LEN INLINE (0..31)
  238|       |
  239|       |    const BASE_BITS: u32 = 18;
  240|       |    const CLASS_BITS: u32 = 3;
  241|       |    const PTR_BITS: u32 = 2;
  242|       |    const ARR_BITS: u32 = 5;
  243|       |
  244|       |    const BASE_SHIFT: u32 = 0;
  245|       |    const CLASS_SHIFT: u32 = Self::BASE_BITS;
  246|       |    const PTR_SHIFT: u32 = Self::CLASS_SHIFT + Self::CLASS_BITS;
  247|       |    const ARR_SHIFT: u32 = Self::PTR_SHIFT + Self::PTR_BITS;
  248|       |
  249|       |    const BASE_MASK: u32 = (1 << Self::BASE_BITS) - 1;
  250|       |    const CLASS_MASK: u32 = (1 << Self::CLASS_BITS) - 1;
  251|       |    const PTR_MASK: u32 = (1 << Self::PTR_BITS) - 1;
  252|       |    const ARR_MASK: u32 = (1 << Self::ARR_BITS) - 1;
  253|       |
  254|       |    #[inline]
  255|  8.29k|    pub fn new(base_index: u32, class: TypeClass, ptr_depth: u8, arr_len: u32) -> Option<Self> {
  256|  8.29k|        if base_index == 0 || base_index > Self::BASE_MASK {
  257|      0|            return None; // Base index must be non-zero and fit in 18 bits
  258|  8.29k|        }
  259|  8.29k|        if ptr_depth as u32 > Self::PTR_MASK {
  260|      1|            return None;
  261|  8.29k|        }
  262|  8.29k|        if arr_len > Self::ARR_MASK {
  263|      1|            return None;
  264|  8.29k|        }
  265|       |
  266|       |        // Validate combinations
  267|  8.29k|        match class {
  268|       |            TypeClass::Builtin => {
  269|  6.42k|                if ptr_depth != 0 || arr_len != 0 {
                                                   ^6.42k
  270|      1|                    return None;
  271|  6.42k|                }
  272|       |            }
  273|       |            TypeClass::Pointer => {
  274|    749|                if arr_len != 0 {
  275|      1|                    return None;
  276|    748|                }
  277|       |                // Pointer depth 0 means "Registry Pointer" (valid)
  278|       |                // Pointer depth 1..3 means "Inline Pointer" (valid)
  279|       |            }
  280|       |            TypeClass::Array => {
  281|       |                // Array len 0 means "Registry Array" (valid)
  282|       |                // Array len 1..31 means "Inline Array" (valid)
  283|    402|                if ptr_depth != 0 {
  284|      1|                    return None;
  285|    401|                }
  286|       |            }
  287|       |            TypeClass::Function | TypeClass::Record | TypeClass::Enum | TypeClass::Typedef => {
  288|    721|                if ptr_depth != 0 || arr_len != 0 {
  289|      0|                    return None;
  290|    721|                }
  291|       |            }
  292|       |        }
  293|       |
  294|  8.29k|        let mut raw = 0u32;
  295|  8.29k|        raw |= base_index & Self::BASE_MASK;
  296|  8.29k|        raw |= (class as u32) << Self::CLASS_SHIFT;
  297|  8.29k|        raw |= (ptr_depth as u32) << Self::PTR_SHIFT;
  298|  8.29k|        raw |= (arr_len) << Self::ARR_SHIFT;
  299|       |
  300|  8.29k|        NonZeroU32::new(raw).map(TypeRef)
  301|  8.29k|    }
